introduction.p:
The learning objectives for this chapter are:
To understand the basic ideas of independence.
To understand and be able to use conditional probability.
To understand and be able to apply Bayes' Theorem.

section.title: Independent Events

statement.p: Suppose that I have two coins, a penny and a nickel. If I flip the two coins, what is the probability that the nickel comes up heads? If I show you that the penny came up heads, does this change the probability of the nickel being heads?

section.p: This exercise is an example of independent events. Given two events A and B, the events are independent if have knowledge of the outcome of one gives no additional knowledge of the outcome of the other. If A and B are independent events, then P(A \cap B) = P(A) P(B). For three events to be independent, they must be pairwise independent. That is, for A_1, A_2, A_3 to be independent, it must be the case that P(A_i \cap A_j) = P(A_i)P(A_j) for i \neq j, where i, j = 1, 2, 3.

statement.p: An executive committee consisted of 10 members: 4 women and 6 men. Three members were selected at random to be sent to a meeting in Hawaii. A blindfolded woman drew 3 names of the 10 names from a hat. Three women were chosen. What is the probability of such luck?
Assume that the probability is $1/2$ that a child will be born a boy. If a family has 4 children, what is the probability that they are all boys?

In recent decades, home pregnancy tests have become quite popular. The tests have become very accurate, but occassionally these tests give wrong results. The test could come back negative while a woman is actually pregnant or postive if a woman is not pregant. Suppose a particular brand of home pregnancy test kits has a rate of 3 per cent of false negatives. That is, there is probability of 0.03 that a woman could have a negative test and actually be pregnant. Suppose 150 women are tested and all the results come up negative. What is the probability that at least one of the women is actually pregnant?
What is the probability that one woman will accurately test as negative?
What is the probability that two women will accurately test as negative?
What is the probability that all 150 women will accurately test as negative?
What is the probability that there will be at least one of 150 women will have a false negative?
What are we assuming for this problem?

p.m: P(\text{at least one pregnancy}) = 1 - P(\text{no pregnancies}) = 1 - (0.97)^{150} \approx 0.98963

section.title: Conditional Probability

statement.p: Suppose that I have two coins, a penny and a nickel. If I flip the two coins, what is the probability that the nickel comes up heads? If I show you that the penny came up heads, does this change the probability of the nickel being heads?

section.p: This exercise is an example of independent events. Given two events A and B, the events are independent if have knowledge of the outcome of one gives no additional knowledge of the outcome of the other. If A and B are independent events, then P(A \text{ and } B) = P(A) P(B). For three events to be independent, they must be pairwise independent. That is, for A_1, A_2, A_3 to be independent, it must be the case that P(A_i \cap A_j) = P(A_i)P(A_j) for i \neq j, where i, j = 1, 2, 3.

statement.p:
You are playing matchmaker and set up your two friends Alice and Bob on a date.
What is the probability that the date will be successful?
Alice calls you right after the date and tells you that she is absolutely enamoured with Bob. What is the probability that the date was successful?

section.p: This exercise is an example of conditional probability. Given two events A and B, P(A \text{ given } B) = P(A|B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)} or equivalently P(A \cap B)= P(B) P(A|B). In other words, if event B is known to be true, then we may say something further about the probability of A.

statement.p: For any three events A, B, and C, prove that P(A \cap B \cap C) = P(A) P(B|A) P(C|A \cap B).

A gumball machine contains 3 red gumballs and 2 green ones. Kaylee really wants to have a red gumball as would her little brother Connor. One gumball is purchased at random and not replaced. Then a second gumball is purchased.
What is the probability that both gumballs will be red?
What is the probability that both gumballs will be the same color?

section.title: Bayes' Theorem

example.p:
Approximately 1 of women aged 4050 have breast cancer. A woman with breast cancer has a 90 chance of a positive test from a mammogram, while a woman without has a 10 chance of a false positive result. What is the probability a woman has breast cancer given that she just had a positive test?
20
40
60
80

statement.p: If an event A must result in one of the mutually exclusive events A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n, then P(A) = P(A_1)P(A | A_1) + P(A_2)P(A | A_2) + \cdots + P(A_n)P(A | A_n).
Prove Theorem for n = 2.

Suppose that we have mutually exclusive events A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n and that S = A_1 \cup A_2 \cup \cdots A_n, where S is the sample space. If A is any event, then P(A_k | A) = \frac{P(A_k)P(A_k| A)}{\sum_{i = 1}^n P(A_i)P(A_i| A)}.

section.p: The statement of this theorem is a bit confusing, so let's see how it works for n = 2. Suppose that S = A \cup A'. Then Bayes' Theorem says P(B | A) = \frac{P(B \cap A)}{P(A)} = \frac{P(B \cap A)}{P(B \cap A) + P(B' \cap A)} = \frac{P(B \cap A)}{P(B)P(A|B) + P(B') P(A|B')}.

statement.p: Prove Theorem for n = 2.
Use Bayes' Theorem to determine the probability a woman has breast cancer given that she just had a positive test in Example?

hint.p: Let B be the event that the woman has breast cancer and A the event of a positive test and calculate P(B|A).

statement.p: Nicole Brown was murdered at her home in Los Angeles on the night of June 12, 1994. The Prime suspect was her husband 0.J.Simpson, at the time a well-known celebrity famous both as a TV actor and as a retired professional football star. This murder led to one of the most heavily publicized murder trial in U.S. during the last century. The fact that the murder suspect had previously physically abused his wife played an important role in the trial. The famous defense lawyer Alan Dershowitz, a member of the team of lawyers defending the accused, tried to belittle the relevence of the fact by stating that only 0.1 of the men who physically abuse their wives actually end up murdering them. Was the fact that O.J.Simpson had previously physically abused his wife irrelevant to the case?

hint.p: Let E be all the evidence, that Nicole Brown was murdered and was previously physically abused by her husband, and G be the event that O.J.Simpson is guilty. Calculate P(G|E).
